text.text: Emmett Till was kidnapped, beaten and murdered in Money, Mississippi after reportedly flirting with a white woman; with the pictures of his open casket funeral, and the acquittal of his captors, the public reaction of Till's death helped spark the Civil Rights Movement.
Rosa Parks  was arrested in Montgomery, Alabama  after refusing to give up her bus seat to a white passenger, inciting the 386-day Montgomery Bus Boycott Reverend Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
Arkansas National Guard was called to prevent African-American students from integrating in the Little Rock Central High School. They were known as the Little Rock Nine.
The Civil Rights Act of 1957, primarily a voting rights bill, was signed into law.
Explorer 1: The first U.S. satellite was launched into space.
Jack Kilby invented the integrated circuit.

text.headline: The Day the Music Died
text.text: usicians Buddy Holly, Ritchie Valens, J. P. 'The Big Bopper' Richardson, and pilot, Roger Peterson, were killed in a plane accident.

The Greensboro sit-ins, sparked by the refusal of four African American college students to move from a segregated lunch counter, began similar widespread acts of civil disobedience  to protest Jim Crow laws.
CIA U-2 spy plane was shot down while flying a reconnaissance mission over Soviet airspace.
Boynton v. Virginia: In a 7–2 ruling, the Supreme Court ruled that African-Americans were protected from racial segregation on buses by the Interstate Commerce Act.

text.headline: Married Life
text.text: The United States broke diplomatic relations  with Cuba.
President Kennedy signed Executive Order 10924, establishing the Peace Corps.
Bay of Pigs Invasion: The failed U.S. led invasion and attempted coup d'état of Cuban Prime Minister Fidel Castro took place.
The Freedom Rides began in Washington D.C. after the failure to enforce the Supreme Court's ruling in Boynton v. Virginia.
Alan Shepard piloted the Freedom 7 capsule to become the first American in space.
President Kennedy proposed the Apollo program, with the goal of 'landing a man on the moon and returning him safely to the earth'.
